awd_titl_txt: Geometry and Arithmetic in Theoretical Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This interdisciplinary research project combines methods and motivating questions arising in theoretical physics with mathematical methods of number theory and arithmetic geometry. Surprising connections between these two very different areas of research have been observed in recent years: the principal investigator has been involved in the study of these relationships between high-energy physics and number theory, and she is currently developing new mathematical approaches towards a better understanding of this mysterious connection.  The goal of this project is to extend this connection beyond its original occurrence in quantum field theory to other areas, including statistical physics, string theory, and quantum information. 

This project comprises several related investigations. The Feynman diagram calculations used in high-energy physics to describe events in particle physics experiments have a rich and not yet fully understood mathematical structure, involving motives and periods of algebraic varieties, which are objects of study in algebraic geometry, arithmetic geometry, and number theory.  This project aims to develop new techniques to improve understanding of these arithmetic structures in quantum field theory. Similar mathematical structures based on periods and motives of algebraic varieties occur in models of modified gravity developed for applications to cosmology; this new, unexpected development will be investigated in depth as part of the research. The project will also study a framework for a discretization of the "holographic correspondence" of string theory, between gravity on a bulk space and conformal field theory on the boundary, built in number-theoretic terms using p-adic numbers. The project aims to develop this p-adic form of the AdS/CFT correspondence into a larger theoretical framework, with a view to explaining in arithmetic terms the emergence of spacetime geometry from information. The work will also continue development of another novel approach to the relation between geometry and information, a construction of anyon models of topological quantum computation based on special solutions (gravitational instantons) of the Einstein equations, with singularities along two-dimensional surfaces. The investigator is also pursuing new number theoretic approaches to quantum statistical mechanics, where the properties of the quantum systems correspond to properties of certain classes of zeta functions studied in analytic number theory, and the equilibrium states of the systems capture Galois symmetries. Finally, the investigator is developing a new approach to distributed computing in theoretical computer science, based on the technique of dynamical triangulations developed in physics as a model of quantum gravity.

por.por_cntn:
The deep relation between Geometry and Theoretical Physics has a long history, going back to the development of the theory of General Relativity, that geometrized gravity through metric Riemannian and Lorentzian geometry, and the subsequent development of the Standard Model of elementary particle physics, that geometrized particle interactions in terms of gauge theory and the geometty and topology of fiber bundles. Finally, the development of String Theory, as a model for the interplay of high energy physics and gravity, further dramatically expanded the role of geometry in theoretical physics. Despite this long history, the field of research involving the interaction between geometry and physics is still in full development and is seeing continuous growth, now also directly involving classical and quantum information. At the same time another new direction of research has emerged, that investigates the role of arithmetic structures in physics, and the interplay between the mathematical fields of Number Theory and Arithmetic Geometry and Theoretical Physics. For long time number theoretic mathematics was seen as pure math very far remote from applications, but this has changed dramatically in recent years, not only because of applications such as cryptography, but also because the presence of arithmetic structures in physical theories like Quantum Field Theory is now understood as a fundamental aspect. The PI's research has the twofold purpose of expanding the interactions between theoretical physics and geometry by incorporating other forms of geometry, such as Noncommutative Geometry (a form of differential geometry designed to accommodate quantum phenomena like the uncertainty principle), and investigating the emerging role of arithmetic structures in different aspects of high-energy physics. Among the results obtained in these directions, the PI and collaborators showed that, in the context of the holographic correspondence of String Theory between bulk gravity and boundary conformal field theories, one can obtain discretizations of the spacetime bulk in a number theoretic way, by replacing the real numbers with the p-adic numbers (expansions in powers of a given prime number). These discretizations allow for combinatorial computations of quantities like entanglement entropy, and a mathematical principle (known as adelic identities) shows that the ordinary physics over the real numbers can be recovered from knowledge of these discretizations for all prime numbers. Other results of the PI involve the algebraic and number theoretic structures underlying the quantum field theoretic computations of Feynman integrals, where the type of values that can be obtained (typically describing events of particle interactions and collisions) can be predicted by the arithmetic geometry of the associated space of Feynman parameters. The PI also continued to explore the role of non-commutative geimetric methods in physics: the results include cosmological models based on a modified-gravity action functional derived from non-commutative geometry. The non-commutative geometry methods also provide important tools for further understanding of the relation between number theory and physics, for example in work of the PI and collaborators showing that some classical number theoretic problems in mathematics (regarding Galois symmetries of abelian extensions of number fields, and more general symmetries of arithmetic spaces like modular curves) can be formulated and studied in terms of quantum statistical mechanical systems. While the use of mathematical methods for modeling physical systems has a very long history, this type of results shows that the converse also can occur, namely theoretical physics models, such as Quantum Statistical Mechanics, can be employed to study and solve pure math problems that are a priori unrelated to physics.
